author: SteveL-MSFT
body: Please use this issue to provide feedback on the published [PSCore6.1 Roadmap](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/powershell/2018/01/24/powershell-core-6-1-roadmap/)

comments.author: JasonFossen
comments.body: What about Desired State Configuration?  You have a roadmap article without a single word about DSC...

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @JasonFossen DSC team posted a [blog](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/powershell/2017/09/12/dsc-future-direction-update/) several months back on future direction.  Nothing to report on their roadmap right now, but it's being worked on.

comments.author: JasonFossen
comments.body:
Michael Greene at the AMA two weeks ago said he would be publishing a new article on DSC soon.  When is this new article coming out please?  Can you or Michael give even general or broad indications about the future of DSC?  Thanks

https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/PowerShell-AMA/DSC-on-PowerShell-Core-6-0/td-p/143758

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @mgreenegit @Indhukrishna any eta on an update on DSC?

comments.author: DaveCarnahan
comments.body:
Newer areas of development for PowerShell in the future? 

How about pushing the envelop on the Out-Gridview cmdlet a bit more?

[1a] Allowing the cmdlet to be fed prompts 
and 
[1b] Get feedback responses from a box so a PowerShell developer doesn't have to write a WPF form

- (more so than just getting back a passthru of records for: many, one or no -passthru arguments).

comments.author: namangoel19
comments.body: Is powershell 6.0 core is supporting Kerberos-based authentication?

comments.author: kborowinski
comments.body: Any update on when responsible product teams are going to provide server side modules (e.g. ActiveDirectory) that will be compatible with PS6?

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
+1 on @DaveCarnahan 

Yes! There's no mention or intention about the suitable replacement to the GUI on Out-GridView.
I like the Python Tk/TCL but I know you guys are trying some other ones.

:)

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
markekraus
comments.body: For those interested in what I have planned for the Web Cmdlets in 6.1: https://get-powershellblog.blogspot.com/2018/01/powershell-core-61-web-cmdlets-roadmap.html

comments.author: LaurentDardenne
comments.body: Is the addition of the '[DSL feature](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/3243)' still relevant?

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @LaurentDardenne the DSL feature is still something I'd like to enable, but it's not a priority for 6.1

comments.author: torgro
comments.body: DSC update is out: https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/powershell/2018/01/26/dsc-planning-update-january-2018/

comments.author: kborowinski
comments.body: Can we ask for C# ternary and null coalescing operators implementation in 6.1?

comments.author: markekraus
comments.body: @kborowinski if you have not already, please vote and comment on #3239

comments.author: kborowinski
comments.body: @markekraus done!

comments.author: Stephanevg
comments.body:
Hi, 
The roadmap sounds promesing, and there seems a lot of work for you guys to achiev.

I had small question:
What about the language / syntax support? 
The article states a lot of new features, but nothing was mentionned about classes:

I have the following few things that keep bugging me when I write classes and would love to seem them appear in a next version:

-Interface creation
-Abastract classes
-Creation of static and non static internal classes
-Implementing comment based help in Classes

These would be really helpfull for the most common scenarios of design patterns.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @Stephanevg can't commit to anything for 6.1 right now for classes improvements.  I have an intern returning as a full time employee on my team starting today.  His intern project was language related, so I'm hoping he can pick up some of the classes improvement work otherwise it'll be part of 6.2 plan.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: I have get/set adding commit over year frozen :-)

comments.author: Stephanevg
comments.body: I have created a separate issue here https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/6418 which could allow the tracking of this easier.

comments.author: dargmuesli
comments.body:
The roadmap says 

> This means that we’re targeting a late June,  early July 2018 release for PSCore 6.1.

It's now August... when can we expect the release of PSCore 6.1?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @Dargmuesli We expect RC in days.

comments.author: dargmuesli
comments.body: @iSazonov nice, what's your estimation of the final (non-RC) release date?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Usually ~2 weeks after RC.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: No new roadmap? No new milestones?

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @iSazonov This is specific for 6.1, will have something regarding 6.2 "soon"

title: PSCore6.1 Roadmap
